reviewText: Back when I was in middle school I had two close online friends who I played games with every night. We played the usual thing middle schoolers played like Call of Duty and some free to play games. One day, one of us had enough money to buy 3 copies of Company of Heroes which was a game none of us heard about but were interested in. For the entirety of 8th grade we played this game religiously. I have so many good memories from this wonderfully made RTS that there is no way I can write a bad review. This game is a perfect 10/10 with a 20/10 for the abundance of mods that exist for it. There are mods for Modern Warfare (Not the COD game, but a conflict between China and U.S.A) with it's own campaign, mods that expand upon existing units and vastly expand the possibilities of the game, mods that feature the Eastern front (USSR vs. Germany), mods that feature the war in Africa, Italy, and Japan, and many, many, many more. This game is a thing of beauty.

TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Company of Heroes: Tales of Valor is a real-time strategy game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ (RIP). This game serves as the second official expansion pack to the series which adds new game types that focuses on micro-management of either a single or small unit sizes, new 'Direct Fire' ability, new mini-campaigns which rewards you with alternate unit models for certain factions and fun new multiplayer modes.

The expansion pack 'Tales of Valor' gives the players three new mini-campaigns. The first one is 'Tiger Ace' which lets the players control a rampaging Tiger I Tank in a small town. The story follows the exploits of Majorgeneral Voss (character from Opposing Fronts) and Hauptmann Schultz (main antagonist of the first game). The second mini-mission is 'Causeway' where the player takes command of a group of paratroopers of the 86nd Air Division in their efforts to secure and hold the La Fiere Causeway which was being used by Allied forces to pass through the Normandy beaches. The last and final mini-mission is 'Falaise Pocket' where the player controls a renegade SS Panzergrenadiers and Wehrmacht soldiers who were ordered to evacuate but defied High Command in order to hold off advancing allied forces and give time for retreating German troops to escape.

PROS:+ New missions are fun to play
+ New units looks nice but... (See CON # 2)
+ New and fun multiplayer game modes like 'Stonewall'
+ Micromanagement gameplay (specially with the 'Tiger Ace' mission) was very fun
+ 'Falaise Pocket' mission was extreme
+ Artwork cutscenes were nice and complemented with good voice acting

CONS:- No new armies or units
- Some new units are just skin replacements
- Mini-campaigns can be completed in a few hours for all three missions (I didn't expect it to be as long as the original campaign or as long as the Opposing Fronts campaign but I didn't imagine that it was this short)
- The 'Directed Fire' feature is very hard to use and is implemented badly
- Tried to do Stealth missions which were implemented (just like the above CON) badly
- This expansion feels rushed

CONCLUSION:Much like a Sherman to a Tiger Tank, this expansion is vastly inferior to the other games. It has its moments with some really intense battles particularly the 'Falaise Pocket' campaign, interesting new game mechanics from 'Tiger Ace' and cool looking replacement units but in the end, it doesn't really add anything innovative to the title. Playing through the campaign missions will leave players feeling that this expansion was rushed and released prematurely.

Normally I would give this expansion a 'Not Recommended' rating but since a 'Complete Pack' exists I highly advice that you buy the aforementioned pack to have the full Company of Heroes 1 experience.

Needless to say, Company of Heroes is one of the greatest games of all time and my favourite RTS. If you are interested in this game and haven't bought it yet, let me just sum up all the things which make Company of Heroes so superb:

+ thrilling campaign with cinematic cutscenes
+ insane multiplayer battles where even a certain loss can be turned into a surprising victory
+ unique resource system that forces you to play aggressively and fight across an entire map
+ completely destroyable environment and sophisticated physics system
+ very detailed graphics compared to other RTS games

With that being said, one could think CoH is almost a perfect game. It indeed is, but there is also a couple of things that sometimes make the game a bit frustrating:

- vehicle pathing. Especially in urban maps with lots of buildings. obstacles, etc.
- cheating AI. Yes, computer player cheats which means it can see the exact locations of all your units at all times as well as your building queues. Additionally, it can also use some abilities in ways human players can't.

So, what are you waiting for? Go get the game if you haven't yet! It's definetely worth the money and it still has a lot to offer, even today.

9/10

reviewText:
The entire Company of Heroes collection is a great RTS, especially for those who traditionally don't like to play this genre of game due to the punishing difficulty on new players (seen in the big name ones, like StarCraft). The fact that this is a World War 2 setting will also draw out some people to try the game out.

CoH doesn't have you building your base and gathering resources, rather it has you capturing points on the maps which provide you with increased resources and army capacity. This lets you worry more about managing position on the battlefield, rather than managing how many drones you have collecting resources. As you play more, you will see little nuances of the game that make the game deeper and more complex, like cover behind walls, flanking, and all the sorts of things you may expect from playing an in-depth, turn-based, strategy game.

Overall, the CoH collection of games have a great single player campaign experience, and a thriving multiplayer community. If you like real-world settings for war, this RTS is probably for you.

Tales of Valor has a much weaker single-player experience than the previous entries. It's really just more of the same, but with a bit taken out. Regardless, it is still worthwhile to have if you are a CoH fan.

Anyone who knows me knows what I think about this game. It's an RTS that does a lot of things differently from the Starcraft/C&C crowd, with brilliant new ideas that make for excellent gameplay. It is, bar none, my favorite RTS of all time.
Resource income is based on control of territory sectors distributed all over the map. Your economy hinges on being proactive and willing to fight to push the front line forward. Turtling in your base is effectively forfeiting the match.
Combat is more nuanced -- less about reflexes and more about tactics. Reading the terrain and making use of environmental cover is a vital skill. Flanking, formations, suppression, combined-arms assaults... very few of these concepts matter in most RTS games of today, but they're all here and all important components of victory in CoH.
I don't know if this game is ever going on sale again, but if you have money to spend, get this game. You'll get a fresh, masterfully-crafted experience, and countless hours of fun in online matches alongside, or against, your friends.

reviewText:
Please note that I am not recommending this game based on it being £9.99 in the store.  Depending on future sales, it may be worth a look if you are a company of heroes fan.

My main beef with this is the length of the campaigns.  You will see that I have played this game for 3 hours, which is the total length of time it has taken for me to complete all three campaigns on a normal difficulty setting.  There is some replay value in attempting to achieve some of the medals for secondary objectives but I would not envisage this taking more than about another hour of gameplay.  So £9.99 for three hours of game play, I don't feel that's value for money.

The original Company of Heroes was/is an exceptional game that rightfully is considered to be one the greatest RTS games ever made.  This game seems to run on the same engine and is a stand alone game to the original so you don't need that to play it.  There are three campaigns, though I use that word in the loosest sense as none of them are very long, all centred around the campaign in Normandy.  Each campaign consists of three missions which are all on the same map (to be clear there are three maps, one for each campaign).  There are two German campaigns and one US campaign.

The first campaign has you in control of one (yes one) Tiger tank for two of the missions, gaining a second for the final mission.  This is a relatively quick but somewhat stale campaign as you're normally used to managing a number of units in combined operations.  The designers (in a nod to Men of War) have also included a direct fire command so you can target enemy units directly with the mouse.  This feature didn't really add anything to the game for me and felt tacked on.

The second campaign has you controlling two US squads with an expanded force later on.  This is slightly more challenging although I question the results of some of the combat as they seem to be 'super soldiers'.  This is challenging given that you are fighting with infantry against vehicles and infantry in fortifications with artillery support.

The third campaign is much better and has you defending a town (Chambois) at the base of the Falaise gap as the German's against relentless Allied ground and air assault.  This is more like the classic Company of Heroes, requiring you to cotrol sectors, build defences, recruit different troop types and muster a defence against a superior enemy.  This for me was the most challenging and enjoyable campaign and one I will play again.

I haven't played multiplayer but there a number of different units that change the unit roster for the various countries.  I can't comment directly but I'm not sure that having an amphibious kubelwagen really adds that much beyond novelty!

I feel that Opposing Fronts adds much more for the single player and multiplayer and if you haven't got that then I'd go for that one first.

I add that I got this game for free in a PC Gamer magazine so for value I'd say that about £0.50 to £1.50 is what I would pay for this.

reviewText:
To be perfectly clear: this is a review for the New Steam Version of CoH.

Company of Heroes is probably my most beloved franchise of all time. So why am I giving this a negative review?

Here's what happened: CoH's original publisher, THQ, went bankrupt and CoH and its development house were sold to Sega. Multiplayer infrastructure is now handled natively through Steam. This sounds great in theory, but in practice, the game suffers from constant, crippling crashes. It really is unplayably bad. It's unconscionable that things could have been allowed to deteriorate so badly, but I suppose it was inevitable that such an old game wouldn't get the love it needed. The gameplay and graphics really do hold up quite well: in fact I'd say it bests CoH 2 in practically all regards.

What a sad and ignominious way for a beautiful game to live out its last days. CoH really didn't deserve to go out with a whimper. If you haven't played the single-player campaigns, you really owe it to yourself to play through the original and Opposing Fronts campaigns, which are brilliant. But as for multiplayer, this game is essentially over, barring the unlikely event that the netcode is ironed out to pre-Steam levels.

Fare ye well, CoH.

Company of Heroes®: Tales of Valor™ is the expansion to the Game of the Year winner and highest rated real time strategy franchise Company of Heroes®. Featuring new campaigns to overcome, units to command, and battlefields to conquer, Company of Heroes®: Tales of Valor™ delivers evolved gameplay mechanics and 3 episodic adventures including 9 new missions, 3 new Multiplayer Modes, and new abilities to master.

- 3 Immersive Storylines — Embark on the definitive WWII experience from all sides of the war. Each episode contains new missions and objectives in a persistent environment.
Episode 1: Tiger Ace: Control Tiger Tank Ace Hauptmann Voss's highly decorated Tigergruppen against the British 7th Armored Division on D-Day in one of the most famous tank battles of WWII. Episode 2: Causeway: Command an American Paratrooper Company in the hours following the initial D-Day landings. Episode 3: Falaise Pocket: Command the Wehrmacht Army as your soldiers try and hold off the advancing Allied army.

- Direct Fire Control — Not only can the player's tactical and strategic decisions influence the battle, but players also directly control units on the battlefield. Players will aim, fire, and maneuver in real-time to capitalize on the changing battle conditions.

- Command New Units — New infantry and vehicles such as the Schwimmwagen and Staghound will be available. The Schwimmwagen is an amphibious, all-wheel drive off-road vehicle while the Staghound is a highly maneuverable 4x4 Armored Car.

- Conquer New Territory — New maps based on famous battles such as Villers-Bocage will be available for competitive players in the online battlefield.

- 3 New Multiplayer Modes — New multiplayer modes to experience with your friends. Become a tank commander and square off in Panzerkrieg, choose a hero unit and join the battle to push back enemy lines in Assault, or team up and defend against waves of attackers in Stonewall.

Tales of Valor is the third, and most likely final, part of the complete CoH experience. ToV, unlike Oppossing Fronts, does not add any new factions compared to the base game. Instead, it adds three new campaigns (Really only two campaigns; Tiger Ace is a three mission mini-campaign) and a plethora of multiplayer features to enhance playing online. Namely, it introduces new units, such as the Kangaroo Carrier or the Swhimmwagen 166. Also, there is three new game types for online play: Assault, Panzerkrieg, and Stonewall. Assault is much like CoH's Defence of the Ancients, with players being hero units fighting to destroy the enemy's base. Panzerkieg is similar to Assault, but with tanks and control points. Stonewall, however, has the player and teammates fighting together to hold back the enemy from capturing the city you are located in. In all, if you are debating to get base over ToV, I'd get ToV. The one campaign you'd miss is nothing compared to the online modes  you'd miss out on.

Happily, there is little evidence of AI advantage in this game, which gives an indication of the thought put into the game by the designers - they have actively programmed in real world constraints, rather than be lazy and not balance the AI, like so many other games in this genre.

Gameplay is easy to pickup, giving newcomers and old hands a smooth introduction into the game. From there, expect to have the hours stolen away from you, as your men valiantly fight off or through Panzers and infantry.

Well crafted game, with plenty of replayability, and with it frequently on sale, there is little excuse not to have this fine game in your collection.

Tales of Valor is the third, and most likely final, part of the complete CoH experience. ToV, unlike Oppossing Fronts, does not add any new factions compared to the base game. Instead, it adds three new campaigns (Really only two campaigns; Tiger Ace is a three mission mini-campaign) and a plethora of multiplayer features to enhance playing online. Namely, it introduces new units, such as the Kangaroo Carrier or the Swhimmwagen 166. Also, there is three new game types for online play: Assault, Panzerkrieg, and Stonewall. Assault is much like CoH's Defence of the Ancients, with players being hero units fighting to destroy the enemy's base. Panzerkieg is similar to Assault, but with tanks and control points. Stonewall, however, has the player and teammates fighting together to hold back the enemy from capturing the city you are located in. In all, if you are debating to get base over ToV, I'd get ToV. The one campaign you'd miss is nothing compared to the online modes  you'd miss out on.
